channel.title: tastytrade: Options Jive
channel.description: If you want to trade like a tastytrader, you have to learn how to talk like a tastytrader. Sit down with Tom and Tony as they dish out and discuss popular trading topics that give you an edge when opening, closing and managing your trades.
channel.itunes:subtitle: Learn to talk the talk - sit down with Tom and Tony as they dish out and discuss trading topics of the day.
channel.itunes:author: tastytrade
channel.itunes:summary: If you want to trade like a tastytrader, you have to learn how to talk like a tastytrader. Sit down with Tom and Tony as they dish out and discuss popular trading topics that give you an edge when opening, closing and managing your trades.
channel.googleplay:author: tastytrade, Inc.

item.title: Some Stats on Reversals
item.description: The odds of an intraday reversal when the market is up or down at least 0.5% is around 1 in 5.  Since increases in market implied volatility also mean increases in expected moves, IV will also be highly correlated with the probability of seeing an intraday reversal.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade
item.itunes:subtitle: The odds of an intraday reversal when the market is up or down at least 0.5% is around 1 in 5. Since increases in market implied volatility also mean increases in expected moves, IV will also be highly correlated with the probability of seeing an...

item.title: Profits per Risk
item.description: Today, Tom and Tony examine the historical data to see how different strategies compare when it comes to maximizing profits while minimizing risks.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade
item.itunes:subtitle: Today, Tom and Tony examine the historical data to see how different strategies compare when it comes to maximizing profits while minimizing risks.

item.title: Managing Different Types of Portfolio Risks
item.description:
When managing a portfolio, it’s important to consider directional exposure, underlying correlations, leverage/account allocation, and tail/outlier risk. Since traders can’t control how the market moves, they can focus on risk mitigation with managing early, trading small and often, diversifying between asset classes, and never allocating more than 50% of the available buying power in a portfolio.

Join Tom, Tony and Jermal as they discuss the various risks that arise while trading a portfolio and methods of handling them.

item.title: Using a Straddle for Expected Move
item.description:
The expected move formula using ATM options is the most accurate estimation for the actual expected move that is easy to calculate.

Since option prices are the drivers of expected move, when IV changes, so will the expected move over every timeframe. Luckily, the platform updates expected move using live data in real time.

item.title: What Happens on Weekends?
item.description: Active traders can be plugged into the ups and downs over the course of the day, but sometimes the market is closed. Do underlyings still exist even when we can’t trade them? Today, Tom and Tony check the data to see how much underlyings move on days when the market is closed compared to when it is open.

item.title: All About Taking Profits
item.description: Managing winners is a key trade management strategy that we have researched and discussed over the years. When used correctly, taking profits early can lead to higher win rates, a better balance of risk and reward, and a decrease in the amount of time we spend holding each trade.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade
item.itunes:subtitle: Managing winners is a key trade management strategy that we have researched and discussed over the years. When used correctly, taking profits early can lead to higher win rates, a better balance of risk and reward, and a decrease in the amount of ...

item.title: How Much Skew is There?
item.description: By looking at the “skew” of put and call options can tell you which direction most of the risk of an underlying’s price action is. Currently, with IV around historical averages, the level of skew is also around historical averages, with SPY 16∆ puts being around 60% to 80% more expensive and 50% further from ATM than 16∆ calls.

item.title: Low IV Definition
item.description: Historically, the largest losses for undefined trades have come when large moves have struck during low IV, which is exactly when purchasing the long legs to define risk is cheap.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade
item.itunes:subtitle: Historically, the largest losses for undefined trades have come when large moves have struck during low IV, which is exactly when purchasing the long legs to define risk is cheap.

item.title: The Benefits of Delta Neutrality
item.description: Being delta neutral is a strategic way to position your portfolio where your profits are not necessarily dependent on the market direction.The beta weighted delta figure in tastyworks helps gauge how directionally exposed you are.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade
item.itunes:subtitle: Being delta neutral is a strategic way to position your portfolio where your profits are not necessarily dependent on the market direction.The beta weighted delta figure in tastyworks helps gauge how directionally exposed you are.

item.title: Mechanics Over Emotions
item.description:
Learn the importance of minimizing emotion while trading. Understand the probability of independent trades failing, and how to combat this with small positioning and a set strategy.

Join Tom, Tony and Jermal as they explain in more detail.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade
item.itunes:subtitle: Learn the importance of minimizing emotion while trading. Understand the probability of independent trades failing, and how to combat this with small positioning and a set strategy. Join Tom, Tony and Jermal as they explain in more detail.
item.content:encoded:
Learn the importance of minimizing emotion while trading. Understand the probability of independent trades failing, and how to combat this with small positioning and a set strategy.

Join Tom, Tony and Jermal as they explain in more detail.

item.title: Risk Reward of Selling Premium
item.description: Theta represents the daily expected return to premium sellers while gamma represents the daily risk that justifies the theta decay.Since theta and gamma are mathematical representations of daily risk and return, we only need to understand one of them when making a trading decision (usually we look at theta) because theta and gamma must always counterbalance each other.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade

item.title: Realized Vol In High IV
item.description:
It is important to put recent “above average” moves in context...since we know that IV today is above average, the larger price moves we are seeing are actually within expectation. 

Knowing what IV is at any point can give you a reasonable expectation of not only option premium, but also the best expectation of the magnitude of underlying price moves.

item.title: Understated Earnings
item.description: Historically, implied volatility has slightly over-predicted price moves. This is a key source of the statistical edge that drives tastytraders to trade short premium. But volatility around earnings is different from typical volatility. Today, Tom and Tony look at the data to see if this IV overstatement edge can be relied upon for earnings trades.

item.title: The Ebb and Flow of the VIX
item.description: The hawkish stance from the Fed on Nov. 24 was the backdrop, but the emergence of the omicron Covid-19 variant was the real impetus for the recent increase in volatility. How does this rise compare to the others seen this year? Join @jermalchandler, Tom and @Tony Battista as they explain.

item.title: How Volatile Are Earnings Days?
item.description:
When trading on earnings days, it would be helpful to have a contextual understanding of the underlying price moves that come on earnings days compared to non-earnings days.

So in this segment we ask: how much more volatile are the price moves on earnings days vs any other day? Tom and Tony dig into the stats to find out.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade
item.itunes:subtitle:

item.title: ITM Put vs. Covered Call
item.description:
ITM Puts and Covered calls offer us the exact same portfolio exposure--so then why choose one over the other? tastytrade digs into where the differences lie.

And check out the Market Measures Some Stats About Covered Calls segment to see us backtest two strategies to see how returns would have looked in the past 15 years!
